### 1. Twitter/X (280 chars)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A mass on a spring follows x(t) = A·cos(ω₀t + φ) where ω₀ = √(k/m)

Built a Python simulation showing perfect energy conservation: kinetic ↔ potential exchange with E = ½kA² = constant

Code + plots below

#Python #Physics #Science

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

### 2. Bluesky (300 chars)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Simple Harmonic Oscillator deep-dive

Equation: d²x/dt² + ω₀²x = 0
Solution: x(t) = A·cos(ω₀t + φ)

Implemented numerical integration with scipy's odeint - achieved ~10⁻¹⁴ m position error vs analytical solution.

Phase space trajectory forms perfect ellipse showing energy conservation.

#Physics #Python

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

### 3. Threads (500 chars)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The simple harmonic oscillator is everywhere in physics - from springs to pendulums to quantum mechanics!

The math is elegant:
- Force: F = -kx (Hooke's Law)
- Solution: x(t) = A·cos(ω₀t + φ)
- Energy: E = ½mv² + ½kx² = constant

I coded this up in Python using scipy's odeint solver. The numerical solution matches the analytical one with errors around 10⁻¹⁴ meters - basically machine precision!

The coolest part? Watching kinetic and potential energy swap back and forth while total energy stays perfectly flat.

#Physics #Python #Science #Math

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

### 4. Mastodon (500 chars)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Implemented a Simple Harmonic Oscillator simulation comparing analytical vs numerical solutions.

Key equations (all Unicode-safe):
- d²x/dt² + ω₀²x = 0
- ω₀ = √(k/m) = 2 rad/s for m=1kg, k=4N/m
- Period T = 2π/ω₀ ≈ 3.14s

Used scipy.integrate.odeint for numerical integration. Maximum position error: ~10⁻¹⁴ m against analytical x(t) = x₀cos(ω₀t) + (v₀/ω₀)sin(ω₀t)

Phase space shows perfect elliptical trajectory. Energy conservation verified to machine precision.

#Physics #Python #SciPy #NumericalMethods #Science

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

================================================================================
## LONG-FORM POSTS
================================================================================

### 5. Reddit (r/learnpython or r/Physics)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
**Title:** [OC] Simple Harmonic Oscillator - Analytical vs Numerical Solution with Energy Conservation Visualization

**Body:**

Hey everyone!

I put together a Python notebook exploring the Simple Harmonic Oscillator (SHO) - one of the most fundamental models in physics.

**What's a Simple Harmonic Oscillator?**

Imagine a mass on a spring. Pull it and let go - it bounces back and forth. The math describing this is surprisingly elegant:

- The restoring force is F = -kx (Hooke's Law)
- This gives us the equation: d²x/dt² + ω₀²x = 0
- The solution is sinusoidal: x(t) = A·cos(ω₀t + φ)

Where ω₀ = √(k/m) is the natural frequency - it only depends on the spring stiffness and mass, not how far you pull it!

**What I Implemented:**

1. Analytical solution using the exact formula
2. Numerical solution using scipy's odeint
3. Energy analysis showing kinetic ↔ potential energy exchange

**Cool Results:**

- Numerical vs analytical error: ~10⁻¹⁴ m (basically machine precision!)
- Total energy E = ½kA² stays perfectly constant
- Phase space trajectory forms a perfect ellipse

**Why This Matters:**

The SHO is the "hydrogen atom" of classical mechanics. Once you understand it, you can tackle:
- Damped oscillators
- Driven/forced oscillators
- Coupled oscillators
- Even quantum harmonic oscillators

**View the Interactive Notebook:**

You can run and modify the code yourself here:
https://cocalc.com/github/Ok-landscape/computational-pipeline/blob/main/notebooks/published/simple_harmonic_oscillator.ipynb

The visualization shows position/velocity over time, phase space, and energy conservation all in one figure.

Questions welcome! Happy to explain any part of the physics or code.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

### 6. Facebook (500 chars)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ever wonder what happens when you pull a spring and let go?

It's called a Simple Harmonic Oscillator - and the physics is beautiful!

The motion follows x(t) = A·cos(ω₀t), where ω₀ = √(k/m). What's amazing is that energy constantly swaps between kinetic (motion) and potential (spring compression) - but the total never changes!

I built a Python simulation comparing the exact math solution with numerical integration. They match to 14 decimal places!

Try the interactive notebook yourself:
https://cocalc.com/github/Ok-landscape/computational-pipeline/blob/main/notebooks/published/simple_harmonic_oscillator.ipynb

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

### 7. LinkedIn (1000 chars)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Computational Physics Project: Simple Harmonic Oscillator Analysis

I recently completed a computational study of the Simple Harmonic Oscillator (SHO), demonstrating both analytical and numerical solution methods.

**Technical Approach:**

The SHO equation d²x/dt² + ω₀²x = 0 was solved using:
- Analytical: Direct integration yielding x(t) = A·cos(ω₀t + φ)
- Numerical: scipy.integrate.odeint with state-space formulation

**Key Results:**

• Maximum position error between methods: ~10⁻¹⁴ m
• Energy conservation verified to machine precision
• Phase space analysis confirms elliptical trajectories

**Skills Demonstrated:**

- Differential equation modeling
- Numerical integration techniques (ODE solvers)
- Scientific visualization with matplotlib
- Validation methodology (analytical vs numerical comparison)

**Why It Matters:**

The SHO serves as the foundation for understanding oscillatory systems across engineering and physics - from mechanical vibrations to electrical circuits to quantum mechanics.

View the full analysis with interactive code:
https://cocalc.com/github/Ok-landscape/computational-pipeline/blob/main/notebooks/published/simple_harmonic_oscillator.ipynb

#ComputationalPhysics #Python #NumericalMethods #SciPy #DataScience #Engineering

### 8. Instagram (500 chars)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Simple Harmonic Oscillator

The physics of a bouncing spring - visualized!

This plot shows:
• Position oscillating over time (top left)
• Velocity & acceleration waves (top right)
• Phase space ellipse (bottom left)
• Energy swapping: kinetic ↔ potential (bottom right)

The equation is elegant:
x(t) = A·cos(ω₀t)

where ω₀ = √(k/m)

Total energy E = ½kA² stays constant - watch the red and blue curves dance while the black dashed line stays flat!

Built with Python, NumPy, SciPy, and Matplotlib

#physics #python #science #math #coding #dataviz #matplotlib #scipy #oscillator #mechanics #visualization #stem #learnphysics
